title: 109_s968
content: CONTINUATION OF SURVIVOR ANNUITIES FOR REMARRIED SPOUSES OF FEDERAL PUBLIC SAFETY OFFICERS KILLED IN THE LINE OF DUTY. The Act titled "Federal Public Safety Officer Surviving Spouse Protection Act of 2005" amends the Civil Service Retirement System to define a "Federal public safety officer" as a law enforcement officer or an employee under this chapter who is a public safety officer. The Federal Public Safety Officer Surviving Spouse Protection Act of 2005 defines a Federal public safety officer as a law enforcement officer or an employee under the Civil Service Retirement System who is performing hazardous duties related to a declared major disaster or emergency. The Federal Public Safety Officer Surviving Spouse Protection Act of 2005 provides exceptions to termination of survivor annuity due to remarriage before age 55 if married for at least 30 years or if the deceased was a Federal public safety officer killed in the line of duty. Remarriage under these circumstances does not affect certain provisions of the law. The Federal Public Safety Officer Surviving Spouse Protection Act of 2005 defines a Federal public safety officer as a law enforcement officer or an employee under specific criteria. The Federal Public Safety Officer Surviving Spouse Protection Act of 2005 defines a Federal public safety officer as a law enforcement officer or an employee meeting specific criteria. The act covers survivors of public safety officers who die in the line of duty or due to a declared disaster, and those determined to have hazardous duties by the Secretary of the Treasury. Termination of survivor annuity due to remarriage before age 55 is exempt if the widow or widower was married for at least 30 years to the deceased officer. The amendments made by the Federal Public Safety Officer Surviving Spouse Protection Act of 2005 regarding survivor annuity will take effect on January 1, 1988, and apply only to remarriages occurring on or after that date.
